passage_text: For the 2013-2014 academic year, one year of veterinary school tuition plus average living costs ranged from $40,000 to $85,000. While some students are able to defray some of the costs through scholarships or private means, the majority of veterinary students must finance their education through loans.

What should be included: 1  A Doctor of Veterinary Medicine degree typically costs $28,000-$54,000 per year for in-state tuition and fees (resident rate) or $41,000-$66,000 per year (for four years) for out-of-state tuition and fees (non-resident rate).

Find out about accredited veterinary schools in your state. Of course, there’s more to consider when it comes to the cost of veterinary school. In 2006-2007, average annual school fees were $3,482 for residents and $4,452 for nonresidents.

Typical costs: 1  A Doctor of Veterinary Medicine degree typically costs $28,000-$54,000 per year for in-state tuition and fees (resident rate) or $41,000-$66,000 per year (for four years) for out-of-state tuition and fees (non-resident rate).

1 A Doctor of Veterinary Medicine degree typically costs $28,000-$54,000 per year for in-state tuition and fees (resident rate) or $41,000-$66,000 per year (for four years) for out-of-state tuition and fees (non-resident rate).

1 The Ohio State University also offers Veterinary Medicine courses. 2  The cost of the tuition fee for the program according to their website can range from $9,045 to $20,758 per quarter for residents and non-residents of the state of Ohio. 3  There are a total of 3 quarters per year.

1 Room and board for veterinary school typically costs $8,000-$13,500 per year. 2  The University of Wisconsin-Madison estimates these fees at $9,730 per year students in their first, second or third years and $12,500 for fourth-year veterinary students.

Veterinary School Costs. According to the Association of American Veterinary Medical Colleges (AAVMC), in 2006-2007, average annual veterinary school tuition was $15,676 for first-year state residents and $28,861 for first-year nonresidents (out-of-state and international students).

Tuition for veterinary students runs about $10,000 to $40,000 per year, or $40,000 to $160,000 total for the four-year doctorate program. Add in the cost of housing, living expenses, books and fees, and the total cost for a doctorate in veterinary medicine can reach $120,000 to $250,000.
